qas.question: Where is the earliest mention of Magadha people?
In the development of which religions did Magadha participate?
Where was the location origin of the Maurya and Gupta empires?
Due to advances in science and culture, what are the Magadha region empires considered to represent?
What were local villages' assemblies called in the Magadha kingdoms?

context: The earliest reference to the Magadha people occurs in the <a0_0>Atharva-Veda<a0_0/> where they are found listed along with the Angas, Gandharis, and Mujavats. Magadha played an important role in the development of <a1_0>Jainism and Buddhism<a1_0/>, and two of India's greatest empires, the Maurya Empire and Gupta Empire, originated from <a2_0>Magadha<a2_0/>. These empires saw advancements in ancient India's science, mathematics, astronomy, religion, and philosophy and were considered the Indian "<a3_0>Golden Age<a3_0/>". The Magadha kingdom included republican communities such as the community of Rajakumara. Villages had their own assemblies under their local chiefs called <a4_0>Gramakas<a4_0/>. Their administrations were divided into executive, judicial, and military functions.
